#Text=Signalling issues and stalled train disrupt service on Singapore 's Mass Rapid Transit lines
#Text=Thursday , November 3 , 2016
#Text=Train services on two of Singapore 's Mass Rapid Transit system lines , both operated by SMRT Corporation , were disrupted at separate times yesterday in two incidents .

#Text=During the morning rush hour , six stations of the Circle MRT Line ( CCL ) were without train service in both directions during the morning rush hour following what SMRT described as " intermittent signal interference " .

#Text=The company first announced the signalling fault on Twitter at 7:37 am , advising commuters to anticipate 10 additional minutes of travel time in the commute between Pasir Panjang and one-north stations .

#Text=The fault was announced rectified two minutes later by another tweet from SMRT , though delays were still expected in the direction of Dhoby Ghaut station due to congestion at stations and on trains .
#Text=File photo of HarbourFront station , 2006 .
#Text=Image : Sengkang .
#Text=SMRT issued another tweet at 8:09 am , alerting commuters to another signalling fault affecting the CCL , on the stretch between Botanic Gardens and HarbourFront stations .

#Text=Initially informing commuters that the issue would add 10 minutes of travel time along the affected stretch , the company later revised this to 20 , and finally , 30 minutes in subsequent tweets , attributing the delays to " intermittent signalling faults " .

column1: #Text=The company later announced via Twitter service unavailable between Botanic Gardens and Marymount stations at 9:06 am , whilst offering free bus services along the length of the CCL .
#Text=SMRT later amended the announcement in another tweet to encompass the stretch between Botanic Gardens and Serangoon stations .
#Text=Train service was restored along the affected stretch by about 10:27 am .

#Text=SMRT had previously experienced disruptions in service on the CCL for five consecutive days in September , also attributable to signalling issues , leading to authorities briefly switching off mobile signals at four CCL stations for two hours on September 2 during investigations .
#Text=Most of the disruptions took place during peak hours , leading to suspicion the telecommunications network could be interfering with the train signalling system .
#Text=After tests proved inconclusive following the lack of a disruption that day , the decision was made to turn off telecommunications signals in the event of another disruption .
#Text=“ It 's very frustrating " , commented a commuter , 41-year-old Joseph Lim .

#Text=SMRT informed commuters of the disruption , between Queenstown and Outram Park stations in the direction of Pasir Ris station , on Twitter at 5:48 pm , attributing it to a  train fault " at Tiong Bahru station .

column1: #Text=In the same tweet , SMRT estimated that the issue would be resolved around 6:10 pm .
#Text=Due to the disruption , the company offered free bus services along the affected stretch in a subsequent tweet .
#Text=At 6:20 pm , SMRT announced on Twitter that it had cleared the disruption by removing the stalled train , and that trains were " progressively return[ing ] to normal speed " .
#Text=The company continued to offer free bus services until 7 pm , when it announced the termination of the service on Twitter .

#Text=In the wake of yesterday 's incidents , commuters criticized SMRT 's handling of the matter on social media , citing SMRT 's failure to provide sufficient information or sufficient buses for commuters , and uploading photos of the congestion .
